I am a commercial clerk—I held four shares in this loan club—I paid 2s. a week—the club met every Saturday at Thorne's coffee room, from 7.30 to 9 p.m., for the purpose of taking the members' money and granting loans—the prisoner's son took the money—he handed it to his father, and then initialled the book—I was present on the sharing-out night on December 19th, when the prisoner said his son had absconded with the money—he produced this sheet of blue paper, and handed his books to me when I asked him for them—they are the day book, ledger, and the I.O.U. book (Produced); they are properly kept by the secretary—a check secretary, a trustee, and a committee-man named Rawlins checked the ledger, which was made up from the day book—the treasurer entered the amounts in the day book when he re
ceived them—the balance sheet has not taken in the full amount, but it is approximately correct—it does not include the dividend paid out, nor the interest that the members paid—about £33 has to be added, including what was due for fines and that sort of thing—the difference would make the amount about £300 for the 237 shares of the 120 members—I was present when the prisoner made a statement to the committee and was questioned as to his duties, as to his handing the money to his son without authority, and if anyone gave him that authority, and he said, "No "—he was questioned further about the bank book, and he said he had not seen it except once casually at his son's house in August, 1905, when he did not take the trouble to look at it—no order was given as to the money being banked, but the members' impression was that it was in the bank—he acknowledged it was in the bank, but when he was questioned as to what bank, he could not give us the name; he gave us to understand that his son had put it in the bank and kept the bank book—he said that he had borrowed about £75 to make up the deficiency for 1904—5—and that in 1903-4 he had borrowed, to make up a deficiency, but he did not say how much that was—he said he knew that he had gives the money to his son, but he never gave us any satisfactory answers—he would not reply to some questions—we have gathered since that he had borrowed £60—he told us that he had banked part of it in 1904 in the three different names of his son, his son's wife, and that of Mr. Rawlins' at the Post Office in Catherine Road, East Ham—I am not sure, but I think there is proof of that—he was asked, "You knew of this, and still trusted your son with the monies?"—he said he did not know—he was asked how long things had been going wrong, and he said two or three years—we said, "You knew things had not been going straight for two or three years?" and he said, "Yes "—the books were supposed to be audited by a committee—they did not do it—I asked a trustee if he had looked into it, and he said that about six months ago a committee had been appointed, made up of the son, the treasurer, a trustee, and one

other member who had declined to be a committee man, and had left them about three months afterwards—the prisoner acknowledged he had not kept a check on anything, although he knew things had been going wrong for three years—the last previous meeting had been held on Satur
day, December 9th—the prisoner was there—his son was not there—he did not know why his son was not there—the books were expected every minute, and I think the treasurer sent for them, and they were brought by a messenger—the prisoner treated it as a matter of course, and took the money—he said nothing on the 9th about his son having absconded—the meeting place was a short distance from his home, and he seemed to be expecting him.

Cross-examined. The prisoner frankly owned he had been grossly careless—the check book was kept by the trustee who called himself the check secretary—that was always Mr. Rawlins—he said this balance sheet had been made up from the members' cards—the prisoner met us every week—at first he said the money was banked, but when questioned still further he said he could not tell us—both the secretary and the treasurer were sitting at the same table when the money was paid to the secretary, who noted it on the member's card and the money was passed on to the prisoner—I cannot say whether he passed it back to his son—it was not handed back to him that I saw—when a member wanted a loan the matter was put into the hands of the treasurer.

Re-examined. There were five members on the committee—one was a trustee—it was a young man who gave up being a member of the com
mittee, as he said it was not convenient to him to continue—I do not know whether he ceased to be a member, but he received a quarter's pay—his place was not filled up—the next appointment was the prisoner, also J. Beard, whom we have not been able to find—he was not a member—the address book is missing—Beard, and the other name, E. P. White, were, I think, imaginary people—I cannot tell if they have been mem
bers—I have been a member two years—a man named Oakley resigned in March, after three months' membership—he was about twenty-one years old—I think he was a clerk—Rawlins, the check secretary, lodged in the prisoner's son's house—one rule provides that a committee of five members be appointed, each one to hold not less than eight shares, and to attend every meeting night, and for their services to receive 7s. 6d. a quarter—I cannot trace in the ledger five committee-men, each holding eight shares—the prisoner held none, though he ought to have owned eight—Rawlins told me he had five himself—when I had a loan the prisoner did not tell me from whom the money was to come—I had to wait alto
gether ten weeks—I wanted £1—I expressed a little surprise, and the prisoner said, "Well, there are so many loans now "—the members were utterly ignorant of the irregularities in 1904—I should not have joined this year if I had known—I was not a member of the committee.

GUY MERCER (Detective K.). On December 23rd I went with a warrant to the prisoner's house, 37, Monega Road—I said to him, "I have a warrant for your arrest for stealing money in connection with the Victoria Temperance Loan and Investment Society, the meetings of which are

held at the Woodgrange coffee shop, in the Woodgrange Road; you will have to come to the station "—I read the warrant—he said, "It is quite true "—the warrant was made out on Todman's information, and charged him with having received property, to wit, £2 12s. on ac
count of William Todman, a member of that society, and fraudulently converting it to his own use and benefit, contrary to the Larceny Act, 1901.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he formed the society about Seven years ago; that his remuneration as treasurer was 12s. a quarter; that the members met from 7 to 9 p.m. each Saturday; that his son was appointed to assist him as secretary at 7s. 6d. a quarter; that there was a committee; that about four years ago he found the duties of treasurer rather onerous and difficult, so he handed the money over to his son, as he had the books; that he had full confidence in him, and did not know what he did with the money; that he retained none of the money that was received at the table; that after making inquiries he found that his son had left the neighbourhood, and then he went to the Romford Road police station, and stated the facts before the inspector in charge; that he meant when he answered the officer, "It is quite true" that it was true that he had entrusted the money to his son; that he handed over to the committee what money was in his hands, together with the books; and that he had no intention to defraud.

div1.p:
JAMES RAWLINS . I have been for some time what is called the check secre
tary of this club—I was also one of the trustees—I was so appointed by the secretary, whom I last saw at the Saturday night meeting on December 2nd—I had lived with him when I was a bachelor, but I am now married—I left him on May 7th—I was present at the weekly meetings, and saw what was done—on opening the meeting the prisoner's son initialled the members' books—the money was paid to the secretary, and not to the prisoner, and at the close of the meeting the secretary would hand what money he had over to the prisoner.

Cross-examined. I did nothing as trustee except having my name on the card—in 1904 only £50 was invested in the Post Office bank in a book of my own—during 1905 I did not ask if it was going to be invested in my name again—I gave up my account; the last year was a bad one—I informed the members what had been done previously, and that there was not so much money in hand the last year as in 1905—that was a bad year, because there was about £75 in arrear when the next year started—I attended the meetings every Saturday night, and received 7s. 6d. a quarter as my salary for doing so as a committee-man and as a trustee—the practice was that the money was first given to the son by the mem
bers, that he then initialled their books and handed the money over to his father—I did not see what became of the money after we left the club room—it was put in a bag which the prisoner's son carried—I made a statement to Mercer and signed it—I told him that the money that was paid by the members each week was first counted by Mr. Symons, junior, and passed over to Mr. Symons, senior—I answered the; question the

sergeant asked me, "Who usually carried the money away?" and I told him the prisoner's son—this is my signature—I did say it was carried away by the prisoner's son—I answered the question when the sergeant asked me that—had he asked the question I should have told him so—I only answered what he asked me.

GUILTY .
Six months' hard labour.

190.
WILLIAM COCKERTON (40) and
LILLIE COCKERTON (38),
Uttering counterfeit coin, well knowing the same to be counterfeit. WILLIAM COCKERTON
PLEADED GUILTY .
MR. PARTRIDGE Prosecuted; MR. MURPHY Defended.

THOMAS COVELL . I am a corn chandler, of 39, Station Road, Manor Park, which is about two miles from Bow—between 3 and 4 p.m. on Friday, December 22nd, a female, whom I cannot now identify, came into my shop for 1/2 lb. of tapioca, price 1 1/2 d.—I served her, getting in payment a florin, for which I gave her 1s. 10 1/2 d. change—I put it on one side, where there were no other florins—the female left the shop with the tapioca—she was carrying this basket (Produced)—this bag is very similar to the one I put the tapioca in (Produced)—my bags have not my name on them—it 9 p.m., when I came to look at the florin and compare it with some half-crowns, shillings and sixpences, I could see it was a bad one, and I communicated with the police.

Cross-examined. Unfortunately I have not a great deal of business—in my neighbourhood people as a rule buy small quantities; there was nothing unusual about this purchase—I do not keep a record of every customer, nor do I keep a descriptive list of the handbags they carry—this is an unusual sort of bag, because it has got cloth handles and the straw is open work—this tapioca corresponds with the best tapioca I sell.

HENRIETTA BARTON . I am the wife of William Barton, of 504, Romford Road, Forest Gate, which is about an hour's walk from Bow—about 3 p.m. on December 22nd the female prisoner came into the shop and asked for a pennyworth of crumpets and two scones, which would be 2d.—I put them in a bag and gave them to her, and she laid down a florin on the counter—I took it up and tried it on a small piece of slate we had on the counter and I noticed it made a greasy soft mark, by which I came to the conclusion that it was bad—I called to my husband and showed him the mark on the slate and said, "This 2s. piece is wrong" in the female prisoner's hearing—on seeing the mark my husband asked her where she got it from and she replied that she did not know—I then marked it across with another coin, so as to deface it, and my husband then handed it back to her and told her to take it where she got it from—she paid for the articles she had bought, but I do not remember what with—I have been shown three counterfeit florins by the police, but this one was not amongst them—the female prisoner left the shop and my husband followed her immediately.

Cross-examined. I should not have noticed that it was bad by the ring—I only noticed it when I marked it on the slate, which I am in the habit of doing with silver coins—there was nothing on the face of the coin to attract my attention—the police came first to me that same evening.

WILLIAM JOHN BARTON . I am the husband of Henrietta Barton—I saw a woman in the shop on December 22nd—my wife showed me a coin and a mark on the slate—I saw the woman go out of the shop and I followed her—I saw a police constable named Armsby, whom I did not know before—I made a communication to him, and pointed out the two prisoners to him.
Cross-examined. Until the coin was scratched on the slate there was nothing to attract my attention to it; it had a good ring on the marble counter.

ALFRED ARMSBY (746 K.) About 3 p.m. on December 22nd I was in plain clothes in the part of Romford Road which runs through Forest Gate, when William Barton said something to me and pointed out a man and a woman to me, whom I followed along the Romford Road towards Strat
ford—I saw them meet another man and the three of them then entered the Pigeons public-house and remained there ten minutes—Detective Pitchley overtook me shortly after they had been pointed out to me by Barton—on coming out of the Pigeons they walked to Forest Gate and went along Woodgrange Road and turned into Osborn Road—they remained then for a minute or so and then the third man left—I did not see anything happen before he left—the two prisoners then went into the Fox and Hounds in the Broadway, Forest Gate—they then came out—the male prisoner kept looking round—when they got into Strode Road we arrested them—I said to the female prisoner, "I am a police officer and suspect you of having counterfeit coin in your possession "—she said, "I have not any "—I said, "I shall take you to the station," and I took her there—she said nothing on the way—directly I spoke to her she pulled 10 1/2 d. in bronze out of her right-hand jacket pocket and said, "That is all I have—on being charged with uttering she made no reply—she produced no money in my presence at the police station—I saw her taken into a room by the female searcher, who I saw come out of the room and hand something to Detective-Sergeant Mercer, but I did not see what.
Cross-examined. There was no bad money, to my knowledge, passed by them at the Fox and Hounds.

THOMAS PITCHLEY (Detective K.) On December 22nd, in the afternoon, I was in Romford Road, Forest Gate, when I saw the prisoners—I and Armsby, who was in plain clothes, followed them down Romford Road towards Stratford, when they stopped at the Pigeons, where they spoke to a man—they all went inside and had a drink and came out again—they came back again towards Forest Gate and turned into Woodgrange Road, went as far as Osborn Road, up which they turned—there the male pris
oner handed something to the other man which I was unable to see—from the time they left the Pigeons until the time they got to Osborn Road would be about fifteen minutes—they then went into the Fox and Hound, which is against Forest Gate railway station, remaining in there ten

minutes—they came out and rejoined the third man; whether he went into the Fox and Hounds I cannot say—the two prisoners then went down Woodgrange Road again towards Danes Road—they turned down Danes Road, when I noticed the male prisoner looking round as if he had be
come suspicious—they then suddenly turned into Strode Road, which is a dark turning; Woodgrange Road is a very big road of shops, and Danes Road is a road with private houses—I then went up to the male prisoner and said to him, "I am a police officer and I believe you to be in possession of counterfeit coin "—he did not say anything—I then put my hand in his right-hand pocket and brought out a florin, which I placed between my teeth—I said, "This is bad "—he said, in the female prisoner's hearing, "Yes, I know it is wrong. I have only got one. I was going to pass them on some of my customers, but you know how it is when you are pushed. I found them, and thought if I could pass them it would help to pay the rent My wife is innocent, as she did not know I had them—I found two counterfeit florins on him altogether—he was taken to the station and charged, when he said, "I plead guilty. My wife is innocent "—I found 6d. in silver and 2d. bronze, good money on him—the female searcher who searched the female prisoner is not here, because there were no bad coins found on her—I saw her take the female prisoner into a room and saw her come, out again—she made no reply when charged—Milton Road, Bow, is about four and a half to five miles from Station Road, Manor Park, and about four miles from Mr. Barton's shop in Romford Road.

Cross-examined. I am given to understand that the male prisoner travels in sausages—they both gave a correct address—I was one of the officers who visited that address—I found nothing in the nature of bad money, nor plant of any description for making it—the female prisoner is separated from her real husband and has lived with the male prisoner as his wife for some years.

GUY MERCER (Detective-Sergeant K.) About 5.15 p.m. on Friday, December 22nd, I saw the prisoners at the Forest Gate police station together, when each could hear what the other said—the male prisoner said "Don't be hard on me; I will tell you all about it "—he then made a statement which I took down in writing after cautioning him—the statement was made in the presence of the female prisoner and read over to her afterwards—(Read): "William Cockerton, 53, Milton Road, Old Ford, pork-butcher's traveller: This afternoon I went to Manor Park to see a friend named Harry Joel, a fishmonger, near the public-house after you get off the horse trams on the right-hand side, to try and borrow 5s. to give me a start for Saturday with sausages. I did not see him. On coming back again to get on the tram I kicked against a piece of paper. I picked it up and found two 2s. pieces in it, which I found were bad. Coming along the road, as I was so hard up, I gave my wife one and said to her, 'Go and get some cakes.' She went into a confectioner's shop on the left-hand side. When she came out she said, 'They told me it is a bad coin. What did you want to give it to me for?' I said to her, 'I did not know it was bad,' hut that was a lie. We then walked down the

Romford Road as far as the Pigeons public-house, and met a young fellow who used to be at a public-house just before you get to Bow Bridge, on the right side. It is called the Fox and Hounds. We had a drink together. I showed him what I found. He said, "What are you going to do with it?' I said, 'I am going to try and get rid of them.' He said, 'That will be a bob a-piece for us.' After that we came back to Forest Gate, had a drink at the Fox and Hounds, near Forest Gate station We then walked up the road to the archway, when we were arrested. On the way to Forest Gate I gave the other man one of the bad coins. He went into one or two shops, and whether he passed them or not I do not know. He only left me a minute when the police officers came along. When he came out of the shops he told me he could not pass them. On second consideration there must have been three coins in the paper I picked up, as I gave the other man one and had two myself. Anything my wife has done in this matter she is entirely innocent of. She had no knowledge that the coin was bad, and only went into one shop "—when I first saw the female prisoner she had this basket and the two bags in it, and I took possession of it—one is a bag bearing the name of Barton and containing two scones and some crumpets, and the other a bag containing tapioca—as I took the buns out of the basket she said, "Those are what I got at a shop up the road"—with reference to the tapioca she said, "I got that from a shop at Bow just after we came out. I do not know the name of the street or the name of the shop "—I said to her, "Yes, we have been watching you for over an hour, and we know very well where you called "—I spoke from what I had been told—she then said, "Well, it is no good telling lies. I suppose you know where I got that from (pointing to the tapioca). My husband gave me another 2s. piece up at Manor Park, and I got 1/2 lb. of tapioca for 1 1/2 d., and they gave me 1s. 10 1/2 d. change "—she made that statement after the male prisoner had made his—as soon as I had finished writing the male prisoner's statement I read it to the female prisoner, who said, "That is quite true "—I then commenced to take the things out of the basket, when she said, with reference to them, what I have already stated—she then made this statement, which I took down in writing (Read): "I have heard the statement my husband has made and signed. It is all true except that I went into two shops. The other shop was a corn chandler's. It was at Manor Park. I bought 1/2 lb. of tapioca. I gave them a 2s. piece which my husband had just given me as we were coming along; I got 1s. 10 1/2 d. change. This is all true "—I saw the female searcher come out of the room where she had searched the female prisoner, and give something to Pitchley—I could not see what it was—the prisoners gave 53, Milton Road, Bow, as their address—I went there and found nothing relating to counterfeit coin—I found a marriage certificate.

Cross-examined. The male prisoner's statement was not read over to the female prisoner to make it evidence against her; the reason was that the male prisoner said to the female prisoner, "This is quite true. Tell them all about it," which showed that he wanted her to corroborate what he had said—I cautioned her before she mode her statement—I found a

separation deed between her and her husband at her address; there may have been a trust deed attached to it—there was a marriage certificate also, showing that she was married to a Mr. Bullock—from my inquiries I find that the male prisoner comes of a very respectable family, having left his home through quarrels—occasionally, when he thinks he would work, he takes about a basket of sausages—he is not a man who works when he can—the prisoners have been living together, I understand, for eight years—they told me they were man and wife.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of Coin at His Majesty's Mint—these two florins found on the male prisoner are counterfeit, and are from the same mould—this one tendered at Mr. Covell's shop is also from the same mould.
Lillie Cockerton's statement before the Magistrate: "I am not guilty. I did not know the coins were bad. "

GUILTY . WILLIAM COCKERTON was stated to be an associate of notorious thieves and had been passing counterfeit coin in the neighbourhood for the past six weeks. MR. MURPHY called evidence as to his good character—
Nine months' hard labour.
LILLIE COCKERTON—
Three months' hard labour.

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul, Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
191.
JOHN DAVYS (40)
, Unlawfully attempting to steal the goods and monies of
James Parker Boswell from his person.

JAMES PARKER BOSWELL . I live at 7, South Grove, Mile End—on December 16th last, at about 11 p.m., I was outside Stratford Market station with my wife and sister-in-law, about to get on to a tramcar—as I was doing so I felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket—I turned round and saw him—I got hold of his wrist and in getting off the car to catch him I slipped and he got away—I ran after him and caught him—I gave him into custody—I do not know whether I lost anything from my pocket or not—the prisoner is the right man.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I was on the step of the car when I caught hold of your wrist—you did not offer me my pipe, as I never had one—I was not intoxicated.
By the COURT. In the pocket where the prisoner put his hand, I had, after I counted it, £1 16s. 6d.

BETSY BOSWELL . I am the last witness's wife—on December 16th, about 11 p.m., I was on the car and my husband was just behind me—I saw him holding the prisoner's arm—I said to him, "What is the matter?" He said, "This man has put his hand in my pocket "—the prisoner got away—my husband caught him and gave him into custody.
By the COURT. My husband was not intoxicated.
Cross-examined. I was not inside the car at all; I was standing on the footboard—I did not see your hand in his pocket—you handed him
a pipe—I said to you that it did not belong to him because my husband has never smoked a pipe in his life.

CHARLES MANNING (414 K.) I was on duty outside Stratford Market about 11 p.m. on December 16th—I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw the prosecutor had hold of the prisoner—the prosecutor gave him in charge—the prisoner said, "The idea your saying that; he has made a mistake. I am a respectable man "—I took him to the station—he was charged and made no reply.
Cross-examined. On the way to the station the prosecutor said a lot to you—he said he would punch your head—he had had a drink or two.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I can prove that I have been at work all the time I have been at home. "

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, said that there were twenty or thirty people trying to get on to the car, and that the prosecutor had made a mistake.

div1.p:
GUILTY . A conviction of felony at Gloucester Quarter Sessions on October 10th, 1902, was proved against him in the name of George Jameson. It was stated that that was after nine convictions for felony.
Twelve months hard labour.

192.
CORNELIUS SALMON (43)
, Unlawfully committing an act of gross indecency with another male person.

GUILTY . It was stated that he had been charged with drunkenness three times. He was otherwise given a good character.
Three months' hard labour.

193.
SARAH ANN JORDAN (39)
PLEADED GUILTY to feloniously marrying
Charles John Gladwell, her husband being alive.
One previous conviction was proved against her.
Six months' hard labour.

194.
FRANK TOMLYN (36)
, Unlawfully carnally knowing Ethel Isabel Lizzie Somers, a girl over thirteen years of age and under sixteen years of age.

GUILTY . He received a good character from the police.
Six months' imprisonment in the Second Division.

195.
GEORGE HERBERT (55)
, Unlawfully committing willful and corrupt perjury.

FREDERICK VERVEY (10 L.) Acting on instructions, I watched 1. Rodney Place, Lambeth, from December 18th, till the 22nd, between 8.30 p.m. and 12.45 a.m.—on December 18th I saw the prisoner come out of the house and go down Rodney Place; he returned in about fifteen minutes, letting himself in with a key; he came out three times after—wards—on December 19th I passed the house at 2.30 p.m. and saw him cleaning the first-floor windows—I saw him again at 10 p.m. that night—on the 20th, between 10.30 and 12.30, he was outside the house, walking: up and down—he entered the house with a key—he came in and out several times every night—on the 21st I saw him about three times that night——on the 22nd I saw him leave the house with a woman, and go with her to a public-house—the prisoner afterwards left the public-house, alone, and returned, letting himself in with a key—he was charged with a woman named Purkiss with assisting in the management of a brothel—I never saw him outside the house with the woman—I have seen them come to the door together—I was present when the warrant was executed on the 22nd at 10.15—the prisoner was with the woman at the time—I found two keys on him, one a latchkey.

ALBERT MASTERS (375 L.) On instructions I kept watch on the house' in question from December 18th to the 22nd—I have seen the prisoner come out and fetch beer—I have seen him go in with a key and come out again and chase boys away every day—I have seen him opening the door for couples—he was in the house with the woman Purkiss, but I have never seen them out together.
JOHN CUNDELL (Inspector L.) On December 21st. at night, I passed this house and saw the prisoner walk up the steps and let himself in with a key.

EUIN BRODIE . I am the wife of George Charles Brodie, and live at 10, Rodney Place, which faces No. 1—I know the prisoner by sight as coming in and out of the house—I have seen him cleaning the windows—I know the woman Purkiss by sight—I saw the prisoner once in her com
pany—they left the house together—that was the morning before Christ—mas, about 10.

WALTER PECKOVER (Inspector L.) On December 22nd I arrested the prisoner and the woman Purkiss—he said, "I have nothing to do with, the place "—I found a latchkey and an ordinary door key in his possession—the latchkey fitted the street door—I was at the Lambeth Police Court on December 23rd when the prisoner and Purkiss were charged with managing a brothel at 1, Rodney Place—after evidence for the Prosecution, the prisoner gave evidence on his own behalf and swore that he had never been in the house before, and said when arrested that he had gone there with a woman—he said he did not know Purkiss and had never seen her before that day.

GUILTY .
Three months' hard labour.

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul, Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
196.
BENJAMIN POPE (30)
, Together with other persons unknown feloniously assaulting
Henry Goddard and robbing him of 5s. 6d. with violence.
MR. WRIGHT Prosecuted; MR. RODERICK Defended.

HENRY GODDARD . I am a dealer and live at 6, Loughborough Street, Kennington—on Saturday, December 23rd, about 7 p.m. I was outside a fish shop in Chester Street, Lower Kennington Lane, buying some fish—the prisoner came up to me with two other men and said, "Are you going to buy some beer?"—I said, "I haven't got no money for beer "—just then my carman came up and handed me 11s. 1 1/2 d.—the prisoner then said to me, "Now you have sot some money, give us a shilling or else we shall snottle you "—he put his right hand in my left hand and punched me on the nose with his left hand—one of the other men with him punched me in the back of the ear—I received two punches and was knocked almost senseless—when I recovered I counted up my money and found I had lost 5s. 6d.—my carman picked me up—I saw the prisoner running one way and the other men another—on December 28th I found the prisoner in custody and charged him—I knew him by seeing him outside public-houses—I have spoken to him—he has asked me for some coppers for breakfast, as he said he had been out all night.

Cross-examined. I knew they called him "Pope "—I have not known him for four years, only about six or seven months—he has never worked for me—I take men on for odd jobs occasionally, but never had him—I should have known if I had taken him on—I know one of Guest's public houses—I might have been in there, but I never drank with him—there was no quarrel between us—I did not hit him—I have lived in the neigh—bourhood for four years—I do not know the other men who were with the prisoner.
Re-examined. I had not seen the prisoner that day before 7 o'clock—I have never had drink with him at any public-house.
By MR. RODERICK. I am a peaceable man—I have had six months' imprisonment for knocking a man down with a poker—I found him in bed with my wife.
By MR. WRIGHT. When he came out of the room he struck me, and I hit him with a poker.

THOMAS SAUNDERS . I am carman to the last witness and live at 5, Gundulf Street, Kennington—on December 23rd I saw my master and handed him 11s. 1 1/2 d.; that was change out of a sovereign—I saw the prisoner and two others talking to him—when I came up I said to the prosecutor, "Here is your change, sir "—the prisoner then said, "You have some money now; we want some beer. I want a shilling; if we don't get it we shall snottle you "—with that he struck him on the head—one of the others struck him behind the head—I was struck on the jaw—my master was knocked nearly senseless—I picked him up—I did not what went out of his pocket—the men ran away—on Christmas morning

the prisoner came up to me and said, "I hear you have prosecuted me "—I said, "I don't wish to say nothing to you at all; you had better get about your business"—he said, "Well, me and my gang will see you're all right "—he walked away.

Cross-examined. I know Guest's house—I have been in there occasionally—I was not in there with my master that very afternoon—I deny that I have had drink with the prisoner—I have seen him, I think, for the last four or five months standing about—I have been in the prosecutor's employ about six months—the prisoner has not been employed by him to my knowledge.

GEORGE CORNISH (Sergeant L) I arrested the prisoner on December 28th on a charge of highway robbery with violence—he said, "All right" when I told him the charge—on the way to the station he said, "I did. punch him in the nose, but I did not steal his money"—at the station he said, "I was the worse for drink or I should not have done it."
Cross-examined. I have heard the prosecutor has been convicted of assault—I do not know the circumstances.'

The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he had done odd jobs for the prosecutor, getting 1s. or 1s. 6d. a time; that he had had drink with him and Saunders in Quest's; that on the day in question he had two drinks with the prosecutor in the Horn and Groom; that a female came in there and the prosecutor asked her to have a drink, but the barman refused to serve it and they all then left; that they got to Chester Street, when the prosecutor said, "Are you going to pay?" that he replied that he had no money, when the prosecutor and the carman both struck him; and that he (the prisoner) them went away and was at home before 7 o'clock.
CHARLES SHADBOLT . I know nothing about the actual fight—on December 23rd I was at the prisoner's place, waiting for him at 7 o'clock, when he came in—we had to meet a mend at 7.30.
Cross-examined. I saw the prisoner that night between a minute or two off 7 o'clock—our appointment was fifteen minutes' walk from there—it would have taken half an hour to walk from Chester Street.

JAMES HENRY SMITH . On the Saturday before Christmas I was assis
tant potman at the Horse and Groom, Newington Butts—I saw the prisoner there with the prosecutor and two others and a woman—I cannot call to mind Saunders being there—it was about 4 p.m.—they were all drinking together—they were refused further drink owing to a woman being served—the prosecutor then made a remark that he had seen me previously at Dartmoor.

By the COURT. The parties here are all strangers to me—that was the first time I had seen any of them—I am quite sure that the prisoner was one of the men and the prosecutor another, and that they were drinking together.
Cross-examined. I have only seen the prosecutor once; I do not think I am mistaken.
Re-examined. Why I remember him is the remark he made to me—I have never been at Dartmoor.

HENRY GODDARD (Recalled). I have made no mistake in what I have said about not being in the public-house—I did not leave my business that day till about 5 o'clock—I never made the remark to the last witness about having seen him at Dartmoor—I was never there.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, FEBRUARY 5TH, 1906.
